rsbNotes.title: 1 John 4:1–6
rsbNotes.text: 4:1–6 God’s gift of His one Holy Spirit stands in contrast to the many lying spirits that drive false prophets into the world to spread opposition to Christ (2:18). Like Paul in 1 Cor. 12:3, John shows how to distinguish the Spirit of Truth from spirits of error: those who confess Jesus as the Messiah are from God, while those who will not confess Jesus are not. This confession is the great divide between those “from God” and those who are “from the world.”

rsbNotes.title: 1 John 4:1
rsbNotes.text: 4:1 gone out into the world. See note 2:19.

rsbNotes.title: 1 John 4:2
rsbNotes.text: 4:2 Jesus Christ has come in the flesh. John distinguishes the gospel from the error of the docetists who said that Jesus Christ was not truly human (Introduction: Date and Occasion). The humanity of Christ was essential if He was to die for our sins.

rsbNotes.title: 1 John 4:3
rsbNotes.text: 4:3 the antichrist. See note 2:18.

rsbNotes.title: 1 John 4:4
rsbNotes.text: 4:4 he who is in the world. In its hostility to God, the world is pervaded by the purposes of the devil, who has captured the human race through temptation (5:19).

rsbNotes.title: 1 John 4:6
rsbNotes.text: 4:6 from God. The Holy Spirit unites believers. See “The Local Church” at Rev. 2:1.

rsbNotes.title: 1 John 4:7–12
rsbNotes.text: 4:7–12 The love of God the Father for “his only Son” (v. 9) is the source of the love that binds the fellowship of believers together as a family. By giving us His Son, the Father introduced us to the perfect love and eternal life that the Father and the Son have always enjoyed.

rsbNotes.title: 1 John 4:9
rsbNotes.text: 4:9 only Son. This means that Jesus is God’s Son in eternity, as the Second Person of the Trinity. The Greek can also be translated “one and only Son,” referring to Christ’s uniqueness rather than to His eternal generation.

rsbNotes.title: 1 John 4:10
rsbNotes.text: 4:10 propitiation for our sins. See note 2:2. Christ turned away the righteous anger of God and satisfied the demands of His justice on our behalf. It was to fulfill God’s love that He did this.

rsbNotes.title: 1 John 4:14
rsbNotes.text: 4:14 Savior of the world. See note 2:2.

rsbNotes.title: 1 John 4:16
rsbNotes.text: 4:16 God is love. God’s love is shown in His covenant faithfulness and in His relentless pursuit of sinners in spite of their rebellion or indifference (v. 8; Ex. 34:5–7).

rsbNotes.title: 1 John 4:17
rsbNotes.text: 4:17 so also are we. Though not like Christ in the completeness of our obedience, we are like Him in our basic orientation, and stand out as He did by contrast with the world at large (John 17:16).

rsbNotes.title: 1 John 4:18
rsbNotes.text: 4:18 not been perfected in love. God’s love is perfect in itself, and it brings to us the sure promise of perfection as soon as we receive it (vv. 12, 17; 2:5). But because we are being made perfect in His love over time (3:2), the remnants of fear may temporarily coexist with love. “Perfected love” from God “casts out fear” progressively rather than instantaneously.
